message.content:
cs.DC, cs.OS, cs.DS, cs.PL, cs.AR 

This paper deals with the design of reader-writer locks, which are commonly used in concurrent programming. The paper discusses the trade-offs involved in designing such locks, particularly with respect to reader scalability. This topic is relevant to several sub-fields of computer science, including distributed computing (cs.DC), operating systems (cs.OS), data structures (cs.DS), programming languages (cs.PL), and architecture (cs.AR). However, given the focus on scalability and performance, we believe that cs.DC and cs.OS are the most likely sub-categories for this paper, followed by cs.DS, cs.PL, and cs.AR.
